ast.name: beatbox tutorial
ast.comment: Learn how to build a sound beat box using boxes. #docs #tutorials #pages

body.text: {template:froi}
In this tutorial, we will build a simple app that displays 3 images and plays sound whenever they are tapped. We learn the basic of building user interfaces using [boxes and pages](/pages).
### let's get started
{box:print}
* open a browser and go to [http://touchdevelop.com/](http://touchdevelop.com/)
* login with your account
* tap **Create Script**
{pic:create script button:15x14}
* tap the **beatbox** template
* pick your app name and tap **create**
{/box}
### a first picture
Let's start by adding a box to display a picture.
* **go to** `[code->main]`
* tap the `[do nothing]` line in the **display** section
* tap on `[boxed]` in the blue keyboard; tap on `[>>]` if you cannot find this button.
{decl:main }
* tap on the `[do nothing]` line under the `[boxed]` statement
* tap on the `[Search APIs...]` textbox and type in **monster**
* tap on one of the monster picture; this will add this picture as an [](/art) resource in your script.
* tap on `[post to wall]`
{decl:main  }
* run your game by tapping on the `[code-> ]` button and see what happens
Yay! The picture is showing on the screen. It might not have the right size but we'll fix that later.
{pic:beat board wall:12x8}
### live editing
{box:portrait}
* Unfortunately, **live editing** is not available in portrait mode because of the screen size constraints.
{/box}
When working with pages and boxes, you can use [live editing](/liveediting) to make changes to your page and see the results in the editor. To enable live editing,
* if you went back to the editor, run your game again
* tap on the `[||]` pause button to pause the script execution. You should see blue lines around each boxes
{pic:beat board paused:10x8}
* tap on the box you want to edit
* tap on the `[edit]` button
{pic:beat board edit:12x8}
* the editor should open on the code that creates the box you want to edit. You will see the live view on the lower right.
{pic:beat board live editing:21x10}
### controlling the picture size
Since the picture might come in different sizes, we will fix the box width to 11 so that it looks consistent. The height will automatically be re sized to match the picture ratio.
* **go to** `[code->main]`
* tap on the line of code where you post an picture to the wall
* tap on the `[+]` button below the code to add a new line
* tap on the `[box]` button; if you cannot find it, use the `[>>]` button to cycle through options
* tap on the `[set width]` button and enter ``11`` through the number keypad
{decl:main       }
* run your game and see what happens
### tap the picture
The next step in building the app is to play a sound when the user taps on the picture. Let's start by adding the code to hook on the _tap_ event for the box that contains the picture.
* **go to** `[code->main]`
* add a new line of code under ``box->set width(...)``
* tap on the `[box]` button
* tap on the `[on tapped]` button
The code under the **where** clause will run each time the user taps on the picture. Let's play a sound when this happens.
* tap on the `[do nothing]` line under the **where handler() is** line.
* tap in the `[Search Apis...]` text box and type **laser**
* tap on one of the sound
* run your app and see what happens when you tap the picture
Yay! The sound is playing! Let's add a second picture.
### a second picture
Adding a second picture is very similar to the previous steps: add a new box, post a picture to the wall, hook to the tapped event and play a sound.
* **go to** `[code->main]`
* tap on `[boxed]` keyboard in the code
* tap on the `[+]` button below boxed. Make sure you selected the entire ``boxed`` statement as shown below.
{pic:add new line under boxed:15x12}
{box:hint}
If you have tapped on a line of code inside of the boxed, you can tap on the `[move left]` button to move the cursor to the left (and out of the boxed).
{pic:move cursor left:12x12}
{/box}
Once the second ``boxed`` statement is added, follow the same steps to add the second picture.
{decl:main    }
* run your game and see what happens
Yay! The 2 pictures show up and I can tap on them. Let's start fixing their size and position.
### thinking in boxes
We are going to build the user interface build placing and nesting boxes. Boxes have tons of options to control their size, alignment and layout.
For example, the pictures are currently stacked on top of each other. That is the default behavior of boxes. Let's add the code so that they are stacked horizontally.
### wrapping up the pictures in a box
The first step in making the boxes layout horizontally is to place them inside of another box. Instead of cutting and pasting code around, let's use a shortcut of the editor to do just that.
* tap on the first ``boxed`` statement in the code
* tap on the `[mark]` button on the lower right of the line of code
{pic:select and mark:21x10}
* drag the lower anchor until box ``boxed`` statement are selected
{pic:selected code:15x8}
* tap on the `[boxed]` button under **surround with** in the **script explorer** view
{pic:surround with boxed:15x12}
The resulting code should look as follow. Notice how the 2 ``boxed`` statement are nested under another ``boxed`` statement.
{decl:main     }
### horizontal layout
Now that we have an outer box containing the two pictures, we can change the layout so that they are placed horizontally.
* tap on the ``boxed`` statement containing the first picture
* tap on the `[+]` **above** the line
* add the following code
{decl:main      }
* run your game and see what happens
Yay! The pictures are stacking up horizontally now!
### using the entire screen
We would like to have the picture use the entire screen space. For that, we need to do 2 things: tell the box to **stretch** across the entire screen and **center** the picture boxes.
* **go to** `[code->main]`
* add highlighted code under `box->use horizontal layout`.
{highlight}
{/highlight}
* run your game and see what happens
Yay! The pictures are centered across the screen!
The final code for this tutorial looks like this:
{decl:main        }
{highlight}
{/highlight}
{highlight}
{/highlight}
{highlight}
{/highlight}
